articles.headline: Central Banks Act With a New Boldness to Revitalize Economies
articles.snippet: With governments unable to revive economies, central bankers are taking increasingly aggressive action.
articles.abstract: With governments unable to revive economies, central bankers are taking increasingly aggressive action.
articles.lead_paragraph: When James Bullard, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, arrived in Frankfurt last week, he issued an unusual public warning to the European Central Bank: Be bolder.
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum, Jack Ewing, Hiroko Tabuchi and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Anti-West Hard-Liner Gains in Iranian Race
articles.snippet: Saeed Jalili, a protégé of Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, is the establishment’s favorite in the presidential election, an unsettling prospect for relations with the West.
articles.abstract: Saeed Jalili, a protégé of Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, is the establishment’s favorite in the presidential election, an unsettling prospect for relations with the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — At his first presidential campaign rally, Saeed Jalili on Friday welcomed the cheers of thousands of young men as he hauled himself onto the stage. His movements were hampered by a prosthetic leg, a badge of honor from his days as a young Revolutionary Guards member in Iran’s great trench war with Iraq.

articles.headline: The Trouble With Taxing Corporations
articles.snippet: If corporations generate “stateless” income — beyond the reach of tax authorities — then governments should probably look outside the corporate sector for revenue.
articles.abstract: If corporations generate “stateless” income — beyond the reach of tax authorities — then governments should probably look outside the corporate sector for revenue.

articles.headline: Switzerland Weighs Deal in Tax Cases
articles.snippet: The proposed agreement with the United States includes a fine of at least $7 billion to $10 billion and the disclosure of the names of banks’ American clients.
articles.abstract: The proposed agreement with the United States includes a fine of at least $7 billion to $10 billion and the disclosure of the names of banks’ American clients.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Swiss government is considering a proposal to disclose bank client names and pay a multibillion-dollar fine to the United States to help resolve a long-running dispute between the two countries over the handling of tax-evasion cases, American and Swiss sources briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Facebook Says It Failed to Bar Posts With Hate Speech
articles.snippet: Facing pressure from women’s groups and its own advertisers, the site said it would overhaul its process for monitoring offensive content.
articles.abstract: Facing pressure from women’s groups and its own advertisers, the site said it would overhaul its process for monitoring offensive content.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook on Tuesday acknowledged that its systems to identify and remove hate speech had not worked effectively, as it faced pressure from feminist groups that want the site to ban pages that glorify violence against women.

articles.headline: A Salvadoran at Risk Tests Abortion Law
articles.snippet: The case of a young woman with a high-risk pregnancy who is awaiting a Salvadoran Supreme Court ruling has become a focal point in a broad battle over abortion in Latin America.
articles.abstract: The case of a young woman with a high-risk pregnancy who is awaiting a Salvadoran Supreme Court ruling has become a focal point in a broad battle over abortion in Latin America.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Beatriz spends her days in a hospital room, anxiously watching her belly grow.

articles.headline: Solar Industry Anxious Over Defective Panels
articles.snippet: When defects are discovered, confidentiality agreements keep the manufacturer’s identity secret, making accountability difficult.
articles.abstract: When defects are discovered, confidentiality agreements keep the manufacturer’s identity secret, making accountability difficult.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The solar panels covering a vast warehouse roof in the sun-soaked Inland Empire region east of Los Angeles were only two years into their expected 25-year life span when they began to fail.

articles.headline: Volcker’s Aim: Responsive Government
articles.snippet: Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, is starting a foundation that will support research, fellowships and conferences focused on making government work better.
articles.abstract: Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, is starting a foundation that will support research, fellowships and conferences focused on making government work better.
articles.lead_paragraph: As chairman of the Federal Reserve, Paul A. Volcker tamed inflation. More recently, he took on the country’s biggest banks in an effort to force them to give up lucrative but risky Wall Street-style trading.

articles.headline: Pakistan Says U.S. Drone Killed Taliban Leader
articles.snippet: A suspected American strike early Wednesday killed Wali ur-Rehman, the deputy leader, two Pakistani officials said, dealing a potentially serious blow to the insurgency.
articles.abstract: A suspected American strike early Wednesday killed Wali ur-Rehman, the deputy leader, two Pakistani officials said, dealing a potentially serious blow to the insurgency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Less than a week after President Obama outlined a new direction for the secret drone wars, Pakistani officials said that a C.I.A. missile strike on Wednesday killed a top member of the Pakistani Taliban, an attack that illustrated the continued murkiness of the rules that govern the United States’ targeted killing operations.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Declan Walsh

articles.headline: Needing Pork, China Is to Buy a U.S. Supplier
articles.snippet: The $4.7 billion offer by Shuanghui International for Smithfield Foods is one of the biggest moves yet by a Chinese company into the United States.
articles.abstract: The $4.7 billion offer by Shuanghui International for Smithfield Foods is one of the biggest moves yet by a Chinese company into the United States.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and David Barboza
